message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history, including recurrent respiratory infections, sinusitis, and meconium ileus, suggests cystic fibrosis. The loose stools that do not flush easily also indicate steatorrhea. Elevated prothrombin time is a common finding in cystic fibrosis due to vitamin K malabsorption. The other options, metabolic acidosis, cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies, are not typically associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recurrent lower respiratory tract infections and nasal polyps in a patient with cystic fibrosis. The mention of loose stools that do not flush easily is suggestive of pancreatic insufficiency. Elevated prothrombin time is a common finding in cystic fibrosis patients due to vitamin K malabsorption. Metabolic acidosis is also common, but it wouldn't be the most likely finding in this scenario. The other options are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest cystic fibrosis, which has a high risk of malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin K, leading to coagulation disorders and elevated prothrombin time. The patient’s lung symptoms also suggest a respiratory acidosis, but no information is given to suggest metabolic acidosis. The patient’s age and symptoms make autoimmune disorders unlikely, so options (C) and (D) can be ruled out.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of recurrent lower respiratory tract infections and sinusitis, as well as the presence of nasal polyps, suggest a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Elevated prothrombin time is a common complication of cystic fibrosis due to abnormal vitamin K absorption. Metabolic acidosis is not a typical finding in cystic fibrosis, and cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies are not relevant to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest cystic fibrosis, which can lead to malabsorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins, meconium ileus, recurrent respiratory infections, and nasal polyps. Elevated prothrombin time is a common finding in cystic fibrosis due to vitamin K deficiency. Metabolic acidosis, cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest cystic fibrosis. Elevated prothrombin time is a common finding in cystic fibrosis due to vitamin K malabsorption. No other options are related to cystic fibrosis or the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of meconium ileus, recurrent respiratory infections, and nasal polyps, which are all consistent with cystic fibrosis. Elevated prothrombin time is a potential complication of cystic fibrosis due to vitamin K deficiency. Metabolic acidosis is also a potential complication, but it would not be the most likely finding in this case. Cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history suggests cystic fibrosis, which can cause recurrent respiratory tract infections, meconium ileus, and difficulty gaining weight. Bilateral nasal polyps and inspiratory crackles suggest respiratory tract involvement. Elevated prothrombin time can be a sign of vitamin K deficiency (common in cystic fibrosis due to pancreatic insufficiency) or liver dysfunction. Metabolic acidosis, cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies are not typically associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis, which are common in patients with cystic fibrosis. The meconium ileus also raises suspicion for cystic fibrosis. The presence of bilateral nasal polyps, loose stools, and low weight percentile further supports this diagnosis. Elevated prothrombin time is associated with liver dysfunction in patients with cystic fibrosis. Metabolic acidosis and the presence of specific antibodies are not typically associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of meconium ileus and recurrent respiratory infections, as well as bilateral nasal polyps, suggest cystic fibrosis. Elevated prothrombin time is a common lab finding in cystic fibrosis due to decreased vitamin K absorption. Metabolic acidosis, cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies are not typically associated with cystic fibrosis.
